Strickgraph¶

Description of knitpieces in manualform¶

Here we will introduce an implementation of a knitting piece via software, with all capabilities, you would ever desire:)

The implementation will be called Strickgraph and a full reference is listed at the end of this section.

First we will introduce, the common representations of knitpieces. Also we will give to every common representation a translation-howto for the implementation Strickgraph. The common representation is as knitting manuals in different styles:

  • hand knitting charts (see eg stitch-maps.com )

  • machine matrices

Machine knitting matrices¶

Todo

implement machine matrice thingies

Hand knitting charts¶

Hand knitting charts are used for row to row implementations, so that you as knitter can knit-as-read.

The implementation Strickgraph has to different kinds of knit charts, that look similar.

First we have a knit-as-read manual, which means in contrast, that the first stitch you make in each row, is the leftmost stitch in the manual. This manual describes a knitpiece via lines of stitches, and you just have to knit in parallel, to what you read, eg:

4 bindoff
4 knit
4 yarnover

Here you start your knitpiece with 4 stitches, knit a right-knit stitches in the next row (also 4). The third row is the last, where you finish your knitpiece, with 4 bindoff-stitches. Note that the read direction is from bottom to top.

We can create an virtual object reperenting this knitpiece via Strickgraph from manual.

from createcloth.stitchinfo import basic_stitchinfo
manual = "4bo\n4k\n4yo"
knitpiece = strickgraph.from_manual( manual, basic_stitchinfo )

Note, that we need a translationpiece for every stitch. In this package a basic translation is given and can be loaded as seen above. It translates our stitchnames (eg ‘yarnover’) and the used symbols (eg ‘yo’), from our manual for the strickgraph.

Todo

We have different things we must discuss here, as startingside ‘right’ or ‘left’. And also the difference of, written-as-you-knit(handknitting) and written-as-you-see(machineknitting) must be further described.

Abstract strickgraph generation¶

Also you can generate a strickgraph with the help of a graph<networkx.Graph>. This is a more abstract generation, but represents the innerstate of our strickgraph.

Short description of graphs¶

Every graph consists of nodes and edges, which connects those nodes. Also every node and edge can have different further attributes.

Generation¶

We need not only a graph for this generation but also the firstrow, which represents in terms of a knitchart our first knitted line. also we need general information about our knitpiece. Eg:

from createcloth.stitchinfo import basic_stitchdata
import networkx
graph = networkx.grid_2d_graph( 4,4 )
firstrow = [ x for x in graph.nodes() if x[0] == 0 ]

asd = strickgraph.from_gridgraph( graph, firstrow, basic_stitchdata )

Handling the strickgraph¶

all nodes and information¶

As mentioned the strickgraph is at its core a graph. This means every stitch is represented via a node and every connection between stitch is represented via an edge.

Acces to nodes:

strickgraph.get_nodes
strickgraph.get_nodeattributes
strickgraph.get_edges_with_labels
strickgraph.get_nodeattr_stitchtype
strickgraph.get_nodeattr_side
strickgraph.get_nodeattr_alternativestitchtype

Rows¶

We can get get rows via get_rows()

strickgraph.get_rows

border¶

We can get a border of the strickgraph. The border should be the outer ost stitch of the strickgraph. That means, if a line (not the last one) just begins with ending some columns(eg per bindoffs) you have those stitches as border of the knitpiece.

Currently the border is just the first and last row, and every stitch at the start and end of each row.

sidemargins¶

The first x-stitches and x-last stitches of each row.

strickgraph.get_sidemargins
strickgraph.get_sidemargins_indices

special stitches¶

strickgraph.get_startstitch
strickgraph.get_endstitch
strickgraph.get_nodes_near_nodes
strickgraph.get_nodes
strickgraph.get_next_node_to

clothfactory-parts¶

To the Strickgraph coresponding factoryleafs are

  • clothfactory_parts.strickgraph.strickgraph.datatypes.strickgraph_container

  • clothfactory_parts.plainknit.factory_leaf.relax_tension

  • clothfactory_parts.plainknit.factory_leaf.relax_pressure

Abstractgenerators:

classmethod strickgraph.from_gridgraph(graph, firstrow: Iterable[Hashable], stitchinfo, startside='right')¶

This method takes a grid and converts it to a strickgraph

Parameters

  • graph (networkx.Graph) – must be convertable to a snake

  • firstrow (Iterable[ Hashable ]) – defines the first row of the graph. is a list of connected nodes from graph: firstrow[i] in graph.nodes()

Physicmethods:

return the row of this node, the start of the row will be the node itself.
